post.title: Which programming language has the most toxic community?

body:
Rust, Haskell, Lisp. All languages with big usability issues that the community pretends don't exist.
On the opposite side, C++ programmers tend to be pretty honest about the language's flaws. So are D programmers -- they are also well aware of C++'s flaws which is why they fixed it. :)
body_html: Rust, Haskell, Lisp. All languages with big usability issues that the community pretends don't exist. On the opposite side, C++ programmers tend to be pretty honest about the language's flaws. So are D programmers -- they are also well aware of C++'s flaws which is why they fixed it. :)

post.body: Just wondering which programming language I should avoid criticizing or else I get bombarded with reee's from their community.
post.body_html: Just wondering which programming language I should avoid criticizing or else I get bombarded with reee's from their community.
post.title: Which programming language has the most toxic community?

body:
I've never really been involved with any language community tbh, I drop in and out as and when needed. Here's my views though, and it should go without saying that just about any tech community is going to have its fair share of political bullshit that you need to be aware of. 

**Rust** is the obvious example. I'll admit it looks like a pretty cool language, and I've had a copy of the book sitting on my desk whilst I find time to work through it, but the community is too preachy. There's a reason that the "*rewrite it in rust*" meme exists.

I view the **JS** community as a lightweight version of the Rust one - it looks friendly at first, but it has a habit of over enthusiastically using JS where it shouldn't be used.

Whenever I've been stuck on a **Go** codebase the community has been quite helpful. Although they too seem unable to accept legitimate criticism of the lang. The discussions around generics were a fine example of that. 

Meanwhile the **Python** community seems to be friendly, and actually willing to admit downsides to the language. Plus they seem self-aware of when Python should be used.

...and a special shout out to the folks at the **PHP** Reddit, who have clearly tried to overcompensate for the "*lol php*" meme by being quite hostile to different opinions. If you disagree with *<insert current trendy RFC or framework here>* then expect  downvotes without any discussion.

The award for the best community I've come across must go to **Erlang** though. Simply because I couldn't seem to find the community, and therefore it was infinitely better than all the others.
body_html:
I've never really been involved with any language community tbh, I drop in and out as and when needed. Here's my views though, and it should go without saying that just about any tech community is going to have its fair share of political bullshit that you need to be aware of.

Rust is the obvious example. I'll admit it looks like a pretty cool language, and I've had a copy of the book sitting on my desk whilst I find time to work through it, but the community is too preachy. There's a reason that the "rewrite it in rust" meme exists.

I view the JS community as a lightweight version of the Rust one - it looks friendly at first, but it has a habit of over enthusiastically using JS where it shouldn't be used.

Whenever I've been stuck on a Go codebase the community has been quite helpful. Although they too seem unable to accept legitimate criticism of the lang. The discussions around generics were a fine example of that.

Meanwhile the Python community seems to be friendly, and actually willing to admit downsides to the language. Plus they seem self-aware of when Python should be used.

...and a special shout out to the folks at the PHP Reddit, who have clearly tried to overcompensate for the "lol php" meme by being quite hostile to different opinions. If you disagree with <insert current trendy RFC or framework here> then expect downvotes without any discussion.

The award for the best community I've come across must go to Erlang though. Simply because I couldn't seem to find the community, and therefore it was infinitely better than all the others.

body:
Really, Haskell's community pretending issues don't exist? I remember long threads on Reddit and GitHub about records (a very basic language feature) and quite a lot of people celebrating on Twitter when (weaker, quite conservative) proposal was finally accepted after like a decade of complaints about poor record situation in Haskell.

I, subjectively, actually find the community to be very critical of even minor things in Haskell. I see a lot of clever hacks, template haskell, compiler extensions and other really complex stuff just to fix very minor inconveniences which in any other mainstream languages are present, usually much more verbose and less safe, but still used and considered a best practice.
body_html:

I see a lot of clever hacks, template haskell, compiler extensions and other really complex stuff just to fix very minor inconveniences which in any other mainstream languages are present, usually much more verbose and less safe, but still used and considered a best practice.

body:
> On the opposite side, C++ programmers tend to be pretty honest about the language's flaws.

That's not necessarily true. I've seen a lot of people who will do some unnecessary complicated way of achieving something that's obviously best implemented procedurally and/or with raw constructs like arrays and pointers, and they'll refuse to do that *just* to avoid "C code". They act like C++ is a completely different and unrelated language to C, and that C is evil and to be avoided at all costs (There is also the flip side, C programmers who hate anything associated with C++). They end up shooting themselves in the foot wasting time creating some insane mechanism to do a task that's very simple to achieve with C-like methods, and then they get slow programs as a result. There are also those who insist on using OOP structures for *everything* no matter what, though they're usually not as bad as in some other languages (and this too has a flip side, where some people refuse to use *any* kind of OOP whatsoever).

There are also those who insist on using OOP structures for everything no matter what, though they're usually not as bad as in some other languages (and this too has a flip side, where some people refuse to use any kind of OOP whatsoever).

post.title: Which programming language has the most toxic community?

body:
>Which programming language has the most toxic community?

Brainfuck. Not because of the name. And not because the people there are bad or anything. Indeed, I'd say anyone messing around with brainfuck is a pretty alright guy. But no, it's a toxic community because now you're programming in brainfuck and there's some serious truth in advertising there. 

>Just wondering which programming language I should avoid criticizing or else I get bombarded with reee's from their community.

All of them. Everyone has religious fevor for the languages they like. This is because the value of the language rises and falls depending on usage. And this has major impacts on our worth and the value of our skills. 50 years ago, if you invested your time/career into Cobol, you can now charge an arm and a leg to transition or maintain banks. They don't have the option of not paying you. There's only so many people like you. And most of them are wealthy and retired.   If, instead you invested into RPGIII, then you're poor and broke on your ass in the gutter with no work in decades.    Talent, skill, and work ethic don't matter for shit when market forces are at play. 

So we care about how popular our preferred language is.   And not all languages are created equal, nor are they suitable for everything, nor do they exist in a vacume.   Rust and Ada are objectively better for serious engineering low level embedded hardware development.  But they just can't compete with the number of C experts out there. So those projects are more expensive or have less hours put in, thus negating any benefit from the language itself.   And god help you if you're crafting webpages in C or Ada. 

So a community that's chill with you criticizing them is a group of hobbists who don't really give a shit if it goes down in fire.  While I'll admit C could be a lot better in different ways for different applications, I'll slit your throat and use what's left like a toilet if you badmouth it or suggest people use something else.
body_html:

Brainfuck. Not because of the name. And not because the people there are bad or anything. Indeed, I'd say anyone messing around with brainfuck is a pretty alright guy. But no, it's a toxic community because now you're programming in brainfuck and there's some serious truth in advertising there.

And this has major impacts on our worth and the value of our skills. 50 years ago, if you invested your time/career into Cobol, you can now charge an arm and a leg to transition or maintain banks. They don't have the option of not paying you. There's only so many people like you. And most of them are wealthy and retired. If, instead you invested into RPGIII, then you're poor and broke on your ass in the gutter with no work in decades. Talent, skill, and work ethic don't matter for shit when market forces are at play.

So we care about how popular our preferred language is. And not all languages are created equal, nor are they suitable for everything, nor do they exist in a vacume. Rust and Ada are objectively better for serious engineering low level embedded hardware development. But they just can't compete with the number of C experts out there. So those projects are more expensive or have less hours put in, thus negating any benefit from the language itself. And god help you if you're crafting webpages in C or Ada.

So a community that's chill with you criticizing them is a group of hobbists who don't really give a shit if it goes down in fire. While I'll admit C could be a lot better in different ways for different applications, I'll slit your throat and use what's left like a toilet if you badmouth it or suggest people use something else.
